marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Chiefly letters to Captain Down in England, from a few men in Charleston, S.C., who were evidently employed to assist in settling a dispute involving W.J. Somers's estate. Somers was Down's father-in-law and lived in the Charleston area. There is also information relating to Down's brother, who was living in South Carolina, and a letter from one of Down's nieces to her aunt in England.
Resident of Staunton (Augusta Co.), Va; wife of John A. Douglas of Loudon Co.

Correspondence reflecting social and economic conditions and referring specifically to the purchase of farmland, weaving and spinning, the birth and growth of the children, and other personal and family matters. An 1825 letter from Thomas Johnson to Isaac Hall (Eleanor's son) contains medical field advancements from the University of Pennsylvania lectures of Dr. Nathaniel Chapman and Dr. Samuel Jackson.
Lawyer; colonel in the U.S. Infantry (War of 1812); politician and U.S. Representative from Charleston.
Collection contains Drayton's routine political correspondence, chiefly concerning appointments and the estate of John Drayton (probably a great uncle).
Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1935.
Protestant Episcopal minister, Halifax Court House, Virginia.
Correspondence from Dresser with officials of the Virginia Bible Society, the American Tract Society, and the Southern Churchman magazine.
U.S. Senator from Illinois; Democratic Party presidential candidate, 1860.

Miscellaneous items from Brander, Williams, and Co. (New Orleans) to Douglas, regarding the marketing of cotton. The collection also includes a letter from Douglas to William Alexander Richardson, an Illinois delegate to the Democratic Party conventions at Charleston, S.C., and Baltimore, Md., 1860. Douglas writes that he has "no hope for the preservation of the Union, except by a faithful and rigid adherence to the doctrine of non Intervention by Congress with Slavery in the Territories," and offers to withdraw his name if the delegates could unite behind another non-intervention, Union-loving Democrat.
Business correspondence, including specifications and orders.
Daybook of a Salem (Forsyth Co.), Va., blacksmith's shop.
Cataloged from card file; description from 1939.
Personal scattered correspondence of the Drew family.
Collection contains letters of a Confederate soldier to his mother and sister, largely describing camp life.

Letters from Union soldiers from Vermont who were stationed in Washington, D.C., Virginia, and Maryland during the Civil War. Correspondence concerns camp life, United States Army hospitals, particularly the general hospitals at Harpers Ferry and Fort Schuyler, and the battle of Culpeper Court House, 1862.
Cataloged from card file; description from 1933.
Private in the Confederate Army; originally from N.C. (Raleigh?).
Dowd's letters home to his family, written while serving in the Confederate Army. Topics concern family affairs and his future prospects.
John C. Hamilton letter to Ferdinand J. Dreer,
Letter to Dreer from John C. Hamilton asking to see his collection of papers of prominent Americans.

Collection consists of a midwife's journal of deliveries. Included is each infant's name, date of birth (and sometimes death), birth weight, parent's name, name of delivering doctor and in most cases a lock of the baby's hair.
Collection consists of a letter concerning the "Maine Law" and temperance reform.
